metadata.title: Multi-dimensional analysis of micro-/nano-polymeric foams by confocal laser scanning microscopy and foam simulations

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Chemical Engineering Science
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/ locate /ces
Multi-dimensional analysis of micro-/nano-polymeric foams by confocal laser scanning microscopy and foam simulations
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ces.2019.07.007 0009-2509/ 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
⇑ Corresponding author at: College of Polymer Science and Engineering, State Key Laboratory of Polymer Materials Engineering, Sichuan University, 24 Yihuan Road, Nanyiduan, Chengdu, Sichuan 610065, People’s Republic of China.
E-mail address: pgong@scu.edu.cn (P. Gong).
Haoyu Ma a, Pengjian Gong a,b,⇑, Shuo Zhai a, Yajiang Huang a, Yanhua Niu a, Chul B. Park b, Guangxian Li a aCollege of Polymer Science and Engineering, State Key Laboratory of Polymer Materials Engineering, Sichuan University, 24 Yihuan Road, Nanyiduan, Chengdu, Sichuan 610065, People’s Republic of China bMicrocellular Plastics Manufacturing Laboratory, Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering, University of Toronto, 5 King’s College Road, Toronto, Ontario M5S 3G8, Canada
h i g h l i g h t s
CLSM was used to construct the 3D cellular structure of scCO2 foamed materials. Fluorescence intensity was the key point to observe the foam structure using CLSM. Foam simulation and CLSM method were used to study the 2D and 3D cellular structure. There is a universal specific conversion coefficient in multidimensional foam structure.
g r a p h i c a l a b s t r a c t

CLSM for foam characterization
Polymeric foam made from scCO2

Article history: Received 30 March 2019 Received in revised form 30 June 2019 Accepted 2 July 2019 Available online 3 July 2019
Keywords: Confocal laser scanning microscopy Fluorescence Multi-dimensional foam morphology Supercritical CO2 foaming Micro-/nano-cellular foams
a b s t r a c t
Multi-dimensional foam structure analysis is critical to identify the properties of supercritical CO2 (scCO2) foamed materials, but most applied analysis only focus on two-dimensional (2D) foam morphology. A novel method of confocal laser scanning microscopy (CLSM), a powerful technique for material structure characterization, is then successfully applied for the first time to construct the multidimensional (including 2D and 3D) foam structure obtained in scCO2 foaming. In CLSM characterization, fluorescent dye is the key point to enhance polymeric foams’ fluorescence intensity so that the multidimensional foam structure is clearly observed. In the multi-dimensional analysis, it is noticed that the statistical cell size via 2D characterization is only 0.79 of that via 3D characterization. This specific conversion coefficient among multi-dimensional foam morphology is further verified in theoretical analysis via micro-/nano-cellular foam simulation. The universal specific conversion coefficient (2D/3D_cell size = 0.79 and 2D/3D_cell density = 1.2) then enables a 3D foam construction for polymeric foams made from scCO2 foaming with only 2D foam characterization data no matter the foam has a micro- or nano-cellular structure.
2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Porous materials are widely used in nature and in our daily life due to their excellent solid-gas combined properties. For example, there are a large number of tiny pores inside the wood
(Berglund and Burgert, 2018; Song et al., 2018), which featured as light-weight structural materials. Human bone is also a kind of porous material, which has the advantages of high mechanical strength and low density (Carpio et al., 2016; Olszta et al., 2007). Furthermore, the organic and/or inorganic porous materials, i.e. polymeric foams (Chen et al., 2018; Ge et al., 2017; Gong et al., 2015; Lee et al., 2017a), silica aerogel (Lin et al., 2018; Patil et al., 2017) and ceramic materials (Sinha Ray et al., 2002; Zhang et al., 2017a) are becoming widely used in our daily life due to their excellent properties, such as high toughness, high specific strength, low density, low thermal conductivity, etc.
Among many porous materials, polymeric foam is one of the most widely used porous material due to its multi-function and the advantage of easy to produce at a low price. For instance, polymeric foam is superior to be used as thermal insulation materials (Gong et al., 2015; Wang et al., 2017a), electromagnetic shielding materials (Hamidinejad et al., 2018; Zhang et al., 2011; Zhao et al., 2019), sound-absorbing materials (Del Rey et al., 2012; Gwon et al., 2016), super-compression materials (Zhao et al., 2013), super oil-absorption materials (Cherukupally et al., 2017; He et al., 2013) and shape memory materials (Tobushi et al., 2004).
Thermoplastic foams made from environmentally-friendly supercritical carbon dioxide (scCO2) foaming is now promoted under the premise of protecting the environment. Blowing agent plays an important role in the foaming process. For example, a large amount of foamed polystyrene (PS) is used as packaging materials, but harmful blowing agents, such as pentane (Gendron and Champagne, 2004), butane (Lee et al., 2009) and 2,2- Azobisisobutyronitrile (Ji et al., 2009) are widely used in PS’s foaming industry. Therefore, an urgent demand arises to develop environmentally-friendly foaming materials (polypropylene, polyethylene, thermoplastic polyurethane (TPU), polylactic acid, etc.), made from green foamingmethods. Furthermore, the scCO2 foamed multi-functional light-weight materials will promote an environmentally-friendly lifestyle due to their excellent performance in noise reduction, thermal insulation, oil absorption, etc. (Cherukupally et al., 2017; Del Rey et al., 2012; Gong et al., 2015; Zhao et al., 2013). Hence, environmentally-friendly scCO2 foaming method has attracted great attention.
As multi-functional foam materials have increasing impact on our daily life, a large number of researchers are devoted to foams’ preparation methods, micro-scale structure and macroscopic performance in recent years. Ferkl et al. (2018) described a model for the simulation of reactive foaming of polyurethane and Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) was used to characterize the mass distribution in walls of polyurethane foams. Lee et al. (2012) studied the sound absorption properties of polyurethane nanocomposite foams, and found that either the decrease of cell size or the increase of cell density leads to the enhanced sound absorption performance. Mantaranon and Chirachanchai (2016) studied the porous morphology of polyoxymethylene foams and found that the impact strength of polyoxymethylene foams increased with increasing the cell density; because the cell walls absorbed impact energy and the bubbles suppressed crack propagation. Ling et al. (2013) studied the microcellular polyetherimide/graphene nanocomposite foams for electromagnetic interference shielding. They found that the dielectric mismatch at interfaces on the cell walls caused the microwave reflection and that the tiny air bubbles in polymer matrix decreased the dielectric constant. These research findings show that the performance of scCO2 foamed materials are greatly influenced by their corresponding foam structure.
Actually, polymeric foam has a three-dimensional (3D) foam structure, which means it is the multiple 3D cells that has a crucial effect on the properties of scCO2 foamed materials. Therefore, an accurate characterization on 3D foam structure is vitally impor-
tant for scCO2 foaming research. Until now, a variety of methods have been applied in the structural characterization of scCO2 foamed materials, such as SEM (Gong et al., 2018; Guo et al., 2019; Ma et al., 2019; Xu et al., 2017), Polarizing Optical Microscope (POM) (Shaayegan et al., 2016; Zalucky et al., 2017; Zhang et al., 2017b) and Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM) (Lee et al., 2017b; Xu et al., 2018; Yu et al., 2016). Unfortunately, all of the above material characterization methods can’t provide the real 3D foam structure for scCO2 foamed materials, but only get the two-dimensional (2D) cross-section morphology of foam samples. Computed Microtomography (lCT) enables a direct 3D analysis of cellular structure, and was used to characterize polyurethane foam (Ferkl et al., 2017) (reactive foaming process) and polyethylene foam (N2 foaming process) whose cell size were larger than 200 lm (Pérez-Tamarit et al., 2018). However, polymeric foams made from scCO2 foaming frequently have much smaller cell size (less than 200 lm) (Chen et al., 2018; Ge et al., 2017; Gong and Ohshima, 2012; Ling et al., 2013), that is much thinner cell walls and correspondingly much weaker X-ray absorption capacity. The difficulty then results in a failure in direct 3D foam structure observation for scCO2 foamed materials via lCT. With no other choice, researchers now frequently use 2D crosssection data (normally based on SEM characterization) to represent scCO2 foamed materials’ 3D foam structure and to predict the corresponding properties. However, the differences between 3D and 2D foam structure could cause a serious mistake in predicting the foam performance at certain situations. For example, when the expansion ratio (EP) is 30 fold, the gas + solid conductivity in scCO2 foamed materials is almost unchanged by decreasing cell size from 100 lm to 10 lm. However, when the cell size is close to 0.1 lm, the corresponding gas + solid conductivity significantly decreases from 29 mW/m K to 10 mW/m K due to Knudsen Effect (Gong et al., 2017). Wang et al. (2017b) emphasized that thermal-insulation and compressive mechanical properties of poly (methyl methacrylate) foams were greatly affected by the cell size of polymeric foams. Lee et al. (2012) studied the sound absorption properties of PU/nano-silica foams, it was found that when the cell size decreased by only 7.1%, the sound absorption ratio of PU/nanosilica foams increased by 30.9% at 1250 Hz. Therefore, the error in cell size characterization using 2D characterization methods based on sample cross section would mislead the study on the relationship between the microscopic foam structure and the macroscopic performance for scCO2 foamed materials. In other words, a 3D characterization method for scCO2 foamed materials is urgently required.
Confocal Laser Scanning Microscopy (CLSM) is a technology for 3D characterization. Compared to SEM, POM and TEM, the main advantage of CLSM is to perform an optical section and to provide micrographs from the bulk of the sample without sample destruction. Therefore, the micrographs obtained from CLSM provide reliable information on the internal foam morphology. Briefly, CLSM works by focusing on a single 2D plane at a selected depth. Micrographs at different depth can then be obtained by changing the position of the focal plane, which is usually called optical section (Marroquin et al., 2011). Besides, transmission mode, reflection mode and fluorescence mode can be applied simultaneously on the sample in CLSMcharacterization to get comprehensive 3D structure. The detailed information can be found in the reference (Ferrando et al., 2005).
The CLSM’s specific laser confocal design enables the 3D construction for a complicated structure. Shah et al. (2015) used reflection and fluorescence mode of CLSM to study Janus ellipsoids, and found that Janus ellipsoids can self-assemble into self-limiting one-dimensional fibers with shape-memory properties. Müller et al. (2017) used transmission and fluorescence mode of CLSM to characterize the 3D microstructure of poly(ethylene glycol)
hydrogel. Wei et al. (2018) constructed the 3D microstructure of highly open porous polyhydroxyalkanoate microspheres by using CLSM and 3D remodeling method. Zhao et al. (2011) constructed the carbon/carbon composites’ 3D surface to study the roughness. Mauko et al. (2009) constructed the 3D micrograph of aged marble to study the intergranular porosity and crack formation. Ilčíková et al. (2016) constructed the 3D structure of Multi-wall Carbon Nanotubes (MWCNTs)/styrene-b-isoprene-b-styrene film to study MWCNTs’ dispersion. Han et al. (2018) used CLSM and a double dyeing technology to investigate the microstructural evolution of a rigid foam structure in whipped cream. Gmoser et al. (2017) used CLSM to study the effect of particles on instant coffee foams. Nilsson (2015) constructed the 3D structure of coffee foams to study the effect of pH and hydrophobic particle additives on the pore size. To study the life characteristics of plants and animals, 3D micrographs of plant tissues (Palmer et al., 2015) and animal cells (Wang et al., 2010) were also constructed, respectively. Therefore, CLSM is a superior characterization method to construct the 3D structure for polymeric foams made from scCO2 foaming.
The simulation method has been increasingly used in the study of porous materials because the random Voronoi method is a suitable tool to construct the 3D foam model. Hwang et al. (2016) used a model soap foam to study the foam’s dynamics. Xiao and Yin (2016) present methods that directly model the random structure of porous media using Voronoi tessellations and studied the porosity-permeability relations. Li et al. (2013) used 3D and 2D Voronoi finite element model to study the thermal properties of closed-cell metal foams. Nachtrab et al. (2011) ana-
Fig. 1. Fluorescence (a) and CLSM micrograph (b) of unstained TPU foa
lyzed the effective linear-elastic moduli of disordered network solids by voxel-based finite element calculations. Zhang et al. (2017a–c) studied the yield properties of closed-cell aluminum foam under triaxial loadings using a 3D Voronoi model. These previous work shows that there have been many studies on the construction of cellular structures using Voronoi method. Since the constructed cellular structure is very similar to the scCO2 foamed materials, Voronoi method was also used in our study to construct the micro-/nano-polymeric foam models for multidimensional analysis.
In our study, TPU foamsat different foaming conditionswereprepared using scCO2 foaming. After stainingwith Nile blue A, the fluorescence intensity of TPU foams was greatly enhanced and could be excited by laser. The 3D structures of polymeric foams made from scCO2 foaming were then successfully constructed by CLSM for the first time. In CLSM characterization, fluorescence mode, transmissionmode and reflectionmodewere studied for the foamstructure’s 3D construction. To compare with 2D foammorphology characterization, SEM and POM were also used to observe TPU foams. It is noted that a specific conversion coefficient exists between 3D foam data and 2D foam data. To verify the specific conversion coefficient theoretically and then further to extend the simple equation from microcellular to nanocellular foam, Voronoi method was used to construct a foam with random 3D nano-/micro-cells. For nano-/ micro-cellular foams made from scCO2 foaming, the statistical cell size based on 2D cross section (e.g. from SEM) is only 0.79 times to that based on 3D foam structure (e.g. fromCLSM), and the statistical cell density based on 2D cross section (e.g. from SEM) is 1.2 times to
m, fluorescence (c) and CLSM micrograph (d) of stained TPU foam.
that based on 3D foam structure. The obtained universal relationshipbetween2Dcross-section foammorphologyand3D foamstructure will greatly promote the research and development of functional polymeric foams with nano-/micro-cellular structure using scCO2 foamingmethod. Furthermore, a new foammorphology characterization method of CLSM enables researchers to obtain one more dimensional information on foam structure for polymeric foams made from scCO2 foaming.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: TPU was supplied by Huntsman (9385) and was used as received. Nile blue A (chemical formula: C40H40N6O6S) was purchased at Alfa Aesar and was used as received. Methanol (purity 99.5%, Chengdu Kelong Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd) was used as solvent for Nile blue A. Carbon dioxide (Linde Gas, purity over 99%) was used as blowing agent.

sections.heading: 2.2. Supercritical CO2 foaming
sections.text:
TPU pellets were dried in vacuum oven at 80 C for 48 h. Twin screw extruder (CTE 20 PLUS, Coperion (Nanjing) Machinery Co., Ltd) was then used to prepare TPU rods at the processing temperature of 180 C and the screw speed of 50 rpm. TPU rods of 2.5 mm in diameter and 600 mm in length were then placed in a highpressure autoclave to dissolve CO2. Before pressurizing CO2, the autoclave was heated to a certain temperature. After the required pressure (10 MPa, 13 MPa and 16 MPa) and temperature (140 C, 145 C and 150 C) were achieved, the TPU samples were held at high pressure CO2 for 3 h to ensure adequate CO2 dissolved in TPU matrix. Then, foaming was induced by a rapid depressurization in 2 s. Nine samples were foamed at the following conditions: sample 1 at 150 C – 10 MPa, sample 2 at 150 C – 13 MPa, sample 3 at 150 C – 16 MPa, sample 4 at 145 C – 10 MPa, sample 5 at 145 C – 13 MPa, sample 6 at 145 C – 16 MPa, sample 7 at 140 C – 10 MPa, sample 8 at 140 C – 13 MPa and sample 9 at 140 C – 16 MPa.
fluorescence mode, (c) reflection mode and (d) multi-channel overlay mode. (For the web version of this article.)
ample 1, (b) sample 2 and (c) sample 3.

sections.heading: 2.3. Nile blue a staining
sections.text: To enhance the fluorescence performance in TPU foams, Nile blue A was used as a fluorescent dye. First, samples were cut into flat sheets and dried for 2 h at 60 C. Second, 5 mg Nile blue A was dissolved in 50 ml methanol to prepare fluorescent stain (0.1 mg/ml, in a beaker). TPU foams were then placed into the fluorescent stain at room temperature for 36 h. Before CLSM characterization, stained TPU foams were washed by deionized water for 3 times and then dried at room temperature.

sections.heading: 2.4. Characterization
sections.text:
Fluorescence Spectrometer (FluoroMax-4, Japan, HORIBA) was used to detect the fluorescence intensity. The wavelength range of the excitation light is 400–560 nm and wavelength interval is 10 nm. Due to the energy loss in emission light, 410–700 nm was set as the emission light wavelength range.
CLSM (Leica SP8) with three excitation light (405 nm, 488 nm, and 552 nm) and a 16-bit photomultiplier light receiving element was used to obtain super-high resolution color CCD images for each foam sample. The HC PL Fluotar 20 /0.40 DRY objective and the 552 nm excitation light was used to excite Nile blue A.
The light intensity was set as 20%. The 562–800 nm wavelength light was received by light receiving element with a gain value of 420. By adjusting lens’ Z-axis position, the optical sections at different depth for TPU foams were then obtained.
SEM and POM were used to study the cellular structure of TPU foams as well. Before SEM characterization, the fraction surface was coated with gold. SEM micrographs were then collected at an acceleration voltage of 25 kV and at a wide distance of 30 mm using SEM (JEOL JSM-606). For POM (Olympus Bx51) characterization, the TPU foams’ cell structure was analyzed directly using transmission mode.

sections.heading: 3.1.1. Fluorescence behavior of TPU
sections.text:
Fluorescence spectrometer and CLSM were used to detect the fluorescence behavior of TPU samples. Unstained samples was excited by the excitation light in a wavelength range of 400– 560 nm and the integrated fluorescence result was shown in Fig. 1(a). It is noted that unstained samples produce no fluorescence at most excitation light, despite the weak fluorescence
-right corner: (a) sample 1, (b) sample 2 and (c) sample 3.
ample 1, (b) sample 2 and (c) sample 3.
response under 400–430 nm wavelength excitation light. The weak fluorescence is highly possible resulted from the added light stabilizers to prevent TPU aging and yellowing (Dubois et al., 2003). The unstained sample was also observed by CLSM using fluorescence mode, but it is difficult to detect any foam structure as shown in Fig. 1(b). Therefore, the fluorescence intensity of TPU foam has to be strengthened to clearly observe the 3D foam structure.
Using fluorescent dye is an effective method to enhance the fluorescence intensity. Fig. 1(c) shows the fluorescence spectrometer result of Nile blue A stained sample, and it is noted that the fluorescence intensity was greatly enhanced at a wide wavelength range of excitation light from 400 nm to 560 nm. The foam structure of TPU foam was then clearly identified using CLSM at fluorescence mode as shown in Fig. 1(d).

sections.heading: 3.1.2. 3D foam structure
sections.text:
Multi-channel acquisition modes of CLSM were applied to observe Nile Blue A stained TPU foam (sample 4). Optical sections of transmission mode, fluorescence mode and reflection mode were collected simultaneously as shown in Fig. 2(a), (b) and (c),
Fig. 6. Cell size ratio among characterizations of SEM,
Fig. 7. 2D cross sections of foam samples via SEM and foam models: (a) sample 1, (b) sam foam model 2 based on sample 20s foam information and (f) foam model 3 based on sa
respectively. And then, they were combined by computer software as shown in Fig. 2(d). By comparing Fig. 2(a), (b) and (c), it is apparent that fluorescence mode and reflection mode are superior to transmission mode when constructing the 3D foam structure. However, the reflection mode gave a blurred internal foam structure compared with fluorescence mode. As for the overlay mode shown in Fig. 2(d), the superposition of micrographs from transmission, fluorescence and reflection, on the other hand, has negative effect on 3D foam structure. Therefore, the fluorescence mode of CLSM is a powerful technique in 3D foam structure construction.

sections.heading: 3.2.1. SEM characterization
sections.text:
Fig. 3 shows the SEMmicrographs of TPU foams (sample 1, sample 2 and sample 3). SEM micrographs of the rest TPU foams could be found in supporting information (Fig. S2 in SI). SEM is the most commonly used characterization method for polymeric foams made from scCO2 foaming (Gong et al., 2018; Guo et al., 2019; Ma et al., 2019; Xu et al., 2017), and it generally represents the
POM and CLSM: (a) dSEM/dCLSM and (b) dPOM/dCLSM.
ple 2 and (c) sample 3, (d) foam model 1 based on sample 10s foam information, (e) mple 30s foam information.
internal cross section of the foam material. These micrographs obtained via SEM characterization were then processed by ImageJ to acquire the statistical cell structure data, such as cell size and cell density (SI, SEM cell size and cell density calculation method).
Fig. S7 shows the average cell size increases with increasing temperature at constant foaming pressure, because of the decreased matrix strength at higher foaming temperature and hence facilitated bubble growth. Fig. S10 shows the cell density increases with increasing the CO2 pressure, because of the enhanced CO2 solubility in TPU matrix at higher foaming pressure and hence facilitated bubble nucleation. Due to the increased cell density, Fig. S7 shows the decreased average cell size with increasing CO2 pressure at a constant foaming temperature.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. CLSM characterization
sections.text:
The fluorescence mode of CLSM is a powerful technique in 3D construction of TPU foams made from scCO2 foaming. Fig. 4 shows the CLSM micrographs of three TPU foam samples (sample 1, sam-
Fig. 8. 3D structure of foam samples via CLSM and foammodels. (a) sample 1, (b) sample model 2 based on sample 20s foam information, (f) foam model 3 based on sample 30s f
ple 2 and sample 3). CLSMmicrographs of the rest TPU foams could be found in SI, Fig. S4. In the process of 3D foam structure construction, defocus occurs when CLSM was used to detect the internal foam structure out of focus plane; because CLSM’s special design (probe pinhole, as shown in Fig. S1 in SI) filters the out-of-focus image. Therefore, only one layer of cell structure (also called optical section) can be observed at a fixed focus depth. The 3D foam structure was then constructed by combining the multiple optical sections at various focusing depths. In Fig. S9, the 3D cell size was obtained by CLSM characterization (SI, CLSM cell size calculation method). Same trend in Fig. S9 was observed as that revealed by SEM characterization in Fig. S7: cell size increases with increasing foaming temperature and decreases with increasing CO2 pressure.

sections.heading: 3.2.3. POM characterization
sections.text:
POM is also a common method to characterize foam structure. Fig. 5 shows the POMmicrographs of TPU foams (sample 1, sample 2 and sample 3). POM micrographs of the rest TPU foams could be
2 and (c) sample 3, (d) foammodel 1 based on sample 10s foam information, (e) foam oam information.
found in SI, Fig. S3. By analyzing the projection of the cellular structure on the focusing plane through ImageJ (SI, POM cell size calculation method), the statistical cell size was obtained. Fig. S8 shows the average cell size from POM characterization, it has the same trend as revealed by SEM and CLSM characterizations: cell size increases with increasing foaming temperature and decreases with increasing CO2 pressure. However, as shown in Fig. 5, due to the projection of random cells on the focusing plane, it is difficult to identify the edge of cells located at the focusing plane. If the projected struts from cells out of the focusing plane were recognized as the edge of cells at the focusing plane, the obtained cell size would be far from the real case, which is the most difficult point using POM to characterize foam structure. In this study, since we already have a sense on the 3D foam structure using CLSM and a sense on the 2D foam structure using SEM, it is possible for us to identify the cells in POM with extreme careful.

sections.heading: 3.2.4. 2D/3D cell size ratio
sections.text:
To experimentally clarify the difference between the statistical cross-section cell size and the statistical 3D cell size, the values of dSEM/dCLSM and dPOM/dCLSM were calculated and the results were summarized in Fig. 6. The cross-section cell size obtained from SEM can be considered as the 2D cell size and the cell size obtained from CLSM can be considered as 3D cell size. As Fig. 6(a) shows, the average value of the 2D/3D (dSEM/dCLSM) cell size ratio for the nine samples was found close to 0.79, which means the 2D cell size via SEM obtained from TPU foam cross section is always smaller than
the 3D cell size via CLSM. The experimental result based on CLSM and SEM in this study reveals a similar cell size ratio with that in ASTM method (ASTM, 2010; Pinto et al., 2013). The cell size of POM and CLSM characterization results was also compared, as shown in Fig. 6(b). The average value of the POM/CLSM cell size ratio for the nine samples is close to 1.04. Hence, the cell size characterized from the projection of the cell edge on the focusing plane is close to 3D cell size.

sections.heading: 3.3. Cell structure simulation
sections.text:
In order to verify the above experimental results, 3D foammodels based on TPU foam samples were constructed using Voronoi method. The detailed procedures can be found in SI. 3D foam information (including 3D cell size and 3D cell density) was obtained by analyzing the foam model directly. As for 2D foam information (including 2D cell size and 2D cell density), the 3D foam model was first cut using a plane, and then the 2D foam information was obtained by analyzing the 2D cross-section foam morphology as shown in Fig. 7. It is noted that the 2D cross sections obtained from 3D foam models were very close to SEM micrographs. It is also noted from Fig. 8 that the constructed 3D foam models were very similar to the 3D foam morphology from CLSM characterization.
As shown in Fig. 9, 2D and 3D cell data (cell size and cell density) was obtained based on the foam model. The average value of the 2D/3D cell size ratio for the 9 models was close to 0.78, consistent with the value of dSEM/dCLSM cell size ratio. The average
ell size, (b) statistical cell size obtained from foammodels, representing 3D cell size, foam models’ cross section, representing 2D cell density, (e) statistical cell density sed on foam models.
value of the 2D/3D cell density ratio for the 9 models was close to 1.21. It is noted that the 2D cell density obtained from cross sections is larger than the 3D cell density; because the cells above and beneath the cross sections were all counted as the cells on the plane, which resulted in mistakes in cell density characterization.

sections.heading: 3.4.1. Cell structure simulation
sections.text:
The foam morphology of polymeric foams via scCO2 foaming covers a wide range of cell size from micro to nano. In order to guide the 3D foam information analysis in scCO2 foaming system, 5 groups (with 3 foam models in each group) of foam models with a cell density of 108–1016 #/cm3, a cell size of 0.074–58.99 lm and an EP of 5–20 fold were constructed using the same mathematic method as described in SI, Fig. S5. Each group of models has the same cell density (Group 1, 108 #/cm3; Group 2, 1011 #/cm3; Group 3, 1014 #/cm3; Group 4, 1015 #/cm3; Group 5, 1016 #/cm3). The 3 foam models in each group have different expansion ratios (EP = 5, EP = 10 and EP = 20).
2D and 3D cell data (cell size and cell density) of the 15 foam models were summarized in Fig. 10. The average value of the 2D/3D cell size ratio for the 15 foam models (including microcellular foams and nanocellular foams) is close to 0.81 and the average
Fig. 10. (a) 2D cell size obtained from foam models’ cross section, (b) 3D cell size obtai density obtained from foam models’ cross section, (e) 3D cell density obtained from foa
value of the corresponding 2D/3D cell density ratio is close to 1.13. The result of microcellular foam models is in good agreement with our above experimental result.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
In this study, TPU foams with a various foam morphology were prepared by scCO2 foaming. For the first time, the 3D cell structure of polymeric foams was constructed via CLSM using fluorescence mode. For comparison, characterization method based on 2D micrograph analysis, such as SEM and POM, were also used to observe TPU foams. It is noted that a specific conversion coefficient exists between 3D foam data and 2D foam data. Furthermore, random 3D nano-/micro-cellular foam models with a various cell size, cell density and expansion ratio were constructed to verify the specific conversion coefficient theoretically and to extend the simple equation from microcellular to nanocellular foam. Based on the experimental and theoretical study, it is clarified that the statistical cell size from 2D cross section is only 0.79 times to that from 3D foam structure, and that the statistical cell density based on 2D cross section is 1.2 times to that from 3D foam structure. Therefore, a 3D foam structure for nano-/micro-cellular foams made from scCO2 foaming could be easily constructed so long as 2D crosssection foam morphology was obtained.
ned from foam models, (c) 2D/3D cell size ratio based on foam models, (d) 2D cell m models, (f) 2D/3D cell density ratio based on foam models.
Declaration of Competing Interest
The authors declared that there is no conflict of interest.
